column1: I looked up KZ Okpala the other day and Wikipedia had this:  > In 2021, Maxwell Stone rated him as the 97th Greatest Basketball Player of All time, directly behind Andre Drummond in his all time rankings.
I didn‚Äôt watch the game. How on earth did KZ Okpala start at SF, play 3 minutes and be a -12?
Where tf is KZ Okpala?

ADDITIONALLY: Meyers Leonard (shoulder) is questionable, Kelly Olynyk (groin) is probable and Gabe Vincent (knee) is probable.

No, they didn't. Sources came out with Houston's asking price.  - Herro, Duncan, Precious & Nunn (combined salary: $9,732,122) - Salary Filler ($31,522,798 worth) - Two 1st-Round Picks (miami only has their 2022/2024) - 4 Pick Swaps (legitimately did not have enough picks to swap)  That means mortgaging the future in two ways: the young players **and** the pick economy for 2-and-a-half years of James Harden. Not to mention that Miami's only way to create the filler would've been to trade Olynyk & Iguodala for Harden at the last minute.  But fuck it, because *Oh please...* came so easily to you, here's what the roster makeup would've looked like fresh out of the trade, completely ignoring that we didn't have the picks or the swaps for Houston.  PG: Goran Dragic/Gabe Vincent (2-Way)  SG: James Harden/Max Strus (2-Way)  SF: Jimmy Butler/Trevor Ariza (who was acquired with a 2027 SRP + meyers)  PF: Nemanja Bjelica/KZ Okpala   C: Bam Adebayo/Dewayne Dedmon (f/a signing)  If you think **that** 10-man rotation does any better against the Milwaukee Bucks than the one we've pushed out there twice, you're completely out of your mind. My flair will tell you I am biased towards the Raptors, but I think it is clear that the Raptors have the most leverage here, with Miami having the least leverage.   Miami needs the Lowry deal to go through and the Raptors want to help, but only if Miami compensates them enough. Achiuwa is clearly not enough to justify taking Dragic's contract. For the deal to go through, Toronto needs to be compensated. This can either come from Miami or Dallas. Dallas doesn't want to give anything of value for Dragic, so they would need compensation as well. Raptors are not going to give anything to Dallas to take on Dragic (obviously), so everything will have to come from Miami. People have floated around 2nd round picks/KZ Okpala, but I wouldn't be surprised if we hear about how Herro will become a sticking point. Miami has been adamant about not trading him, but what would happen if keeping Herro is what makes the deal fall apart? This is just speculation, though. Most likely scenario is KZ Okpala, a lightly protected FRP, and a SRP will be given to the Raptors to absorb Dragic's contract.   I personally think that a Malachi Flynn and Herro swap would be interesting, but Miami would apparently let the entire deal fall apart before they trade Herro.
This would make sense to me as well.  KZ Okpala, a 2nd round pick maybe  more long wings please!

If Toronto/Miami can‚Äôt find a 3rd team to take on Dragic‚Äôs contract, Miami will include additional assets (rumours are a 1st and/or KZ Okpala).

Currently at 75M with only butler, bam, herro, and kz okpala under contract. Add Lowry for around 25M and duncan robinson for around 15M and it's up to 115M. So about 29M left to spend under the hard cap. If they sign and trade for derozan somehow, then the MLE will probably have to go unused.

If we send Dragic (19.4 mill) and Achiuwa (2 mill) for Lowry, we have around 102 million in salary between Lowry, Bam, Butler, and KZ Okpala plus Duncan and Nunn's cap holds of 4.7 million each. The rumor is that Derozan could be slotted into the non-taxpayer MLE of 9.5 million and then we use our Bird Rights on Duncan to match any offer sheets. Miami's hardcapped at this point so whatever is left over, we'll probably use to re-sign Oladipo, Ariza, probably Bjelica, and then I guess we use the bi-annual to sign Dwayne Dedmon again.
